sections.content:

company.
Dividends paid from previously taxed profits shall only be subject to the 10% withholding tax without
further corporation tax liability.

NIGERIA TAX REFORM ACT 2025
PART I - PRELIMINARY
Section 1. Commencement
This Act shall commence on 1st January 2026 and shall apply to all taxable income derived on or
after the commencement date. The provisions of this Act supersede all previous tax legislation
including the Companies Income Tax Act (CITA) and the Personal Income Tax Act (PITA).
Section 2. Interpretation
In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires:
"taxable income" means the gross income of a person for a year of assessment after deducting all
allowable expenses and reliefs as provided under this Act;
"company" means a body corporate established under the laws of Nigeria or any other jurisdiction,
including corporations, partnerships, and limited liability companies;
"individual" means a natural person who is resident in Nigeria or derives income from Nigeria,
subject to personal income taxation under this Act;
"digital asset" means any digital representation of value or contractual rights that can be
transferred, stored, or traded electronically, including but not limited to cryptocurrencies, virtual
currencies, non-fungible tokens (NFTs), and other blockchain-based assets;
"virtual asset" has the same meaning as digital asset;

blocks.text: NIGERIA TAX REFORM ACT 2025
PART I - PRELIMINARY
Section 1. Commencement

This Act shall commence on 1st January 2026 and shall apply to all taxable income derived on or
after the commencement date. The provisions of this Act supersede all previous tax legislation
including the Companies Income Tax Act (CITA) and the Personal Income Tax Act (PITA).
Section 2. Interpretation
In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires:

"taxable income" means the gross income of a person for a year of assessment after deducting all
allowable expenses and reliefs as provided under this Act;

"company" means a body corporate established under the laws of Nigeria or any other jurisdiction,
including corporations, partnerships, and limited liability companies;

"individual" means a natural person who is resident in Nigeria or derives income from Nigeria,
subject to personal income taxation under this Act;
"virtual asset" has the same meaning as digital asset;
PART II - TAXABLE INCOME
Section 3. Taxable Income for Companies

For the purposes of computing taxable income, a company may deduct all expenses wholly,
exclusively, and necessarily incurred in the production of income, including depreciation
allowances, pension contributions, and bad debts written off.
Section 4. Taxable Income for Individuals

An individual shall be entitled to deductions including consolidated relief allowance calculated as
1% of gross income or I200,000 (whichever is higher) plus 20% of gross income.

pages.text:
PART IV - ADMINISTRATION
Section 6. Nigeria Revenue Service
The Federal Inland Revenue Service (FIRS) is hereby replaced by the Nigeria Revenue Service
(NRS) which shall be the primary tax authority responsible for the administration and collection of
taxes under this Act. The NRS shall:
(a) assess, collect, and account for all federal taxes;
(b) enforce compliance with tax laws;
(c) maintain a central tax database;
(d) coordinate with state revenue services.
The NRS shall operate under the supervision of the Joint Revenue Board established under the
Joint Revenue Board Establishment Act 2024.

PART VI - VALUE ADDED TAX
Section 8. VAT Rate and Application
Value Added Tax (VAT) shall be charged at the rate of 7.5% on the supply of all goods and services
in Nigeria, except those specifically exempted under Schedule 2 of this Act.
The following persons shall register for VAT and charge VAT on their supplies:
(a) any person whose annual turnover exceeds I25,000,000;
(b) any person who imports goods or services into Nigeria;
(c) any person who makes taxable supplies regardless of turnover, at their option.
Section 9. VAT Registration for Freelancers
Freelancers and independent contractors need to charge VAT under the 2026 Nigerian tax law if
they meet the following conditions:
(a) their annual turnover from freelance services exceeds I25,000,000;
(b) they provide services that are not exempt under Schedule 2;
(c) they invoice clients registered in Nigeria.
Freelancers with turnover below I25,000,000 are not required to register for VAT unless they
voluntarily choose to do so. Provided that freelancers providing exempt services (such as medical,
educational, or charitable services) are not required to charge VAT regardless of turnover.
